summary: This is a transcript of a December 2, 2019 discovery conference in the defamation lawsuit Virginia Giuffre v. Alan Dershowitz before Judge Loretta Preska. The judge and attorneys debate the scope of discovery, focusing on whether Dershowitz had sexual relations with Giuffre and others at Epstein's properties, and allegations of an extortion conspiracy involving Giuffre's lawyers. This is a transcript of a court hearing in a defamation lawsuit (Case 1:19-cv-03377-LAP). The plaintiff's counsel (C. Cooper) discusses amending the complaint to add new defamatory statements by Alan Dershowitz, state tort claims revived by the New York Child Victims Act, and a Wiretap Act claim. The defense counsel (H. Cooper) argues against the amendments and discusses discovery issues, including seeking records related to the plaintiff's alleged employment at Mar-a-Lago and potential subpoenas for attorney-client communications involving David Boies and Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: The defendant in the defamation lawsuit. The plaintiff seeks to add claims based on new defamatory statements he made in a book. His prior legal representation of Jeffrey Epstein is also a topic for potential discovery.

persons.name: Virginia Giuffre
persons.context: Plaintiff suing Alan Dershowitz for defamation. She alleges Dershowitz sexually abused her and was involved in human trafficking with Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Loretta A. Preska
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case, managing the discovery conference and attempting to limit the scope of discovery to relevant issues.

persons.name: Charles J. Cooper
persons.context: Lead attorney representing Virginia Giuffre. Argues for broader discovery into Dershowitz's conduct related to Epstein to challenge his credibility.

persons.name: Howard Cooper
persons.context: Lead attorney representing Alan Dershowitz. Argues to limit discovery, particularly into Dershowitz's sexual history, and focuses on alleged false accusations by Giuffre against other men.

persons.name: Michael W. Kirk
persons.context: Attorney from Cooper & Kirk representing Virginia Giuffre. Mentions the protective order on Ghislaine Maxwell's deposition.

persons.name: Nicole J. Moss
persons.context: Attorney from Cooper & Kirk listed as appearing for the plaintiff.

persons.name: Haley N. Proctor
persons.context: Attorney from Cooper & Kirk listed as appearing for the plaintiff.

persons.name: Christian Kiely
persons.context: Attorney from Todd & Weld listed as appearing for the defendant.

persons.name: Imran H. Ansari
persons.context: Attorney from Aidala Bertuna & Kamins listed as appearing for the defendant.

persons.name: Barry Kamins
persons.context: Attorney from Aidala Bertuna & Kamins listed as appearing for the defendant.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier and accused sex trafficker. The transcript discusses Alan Dershowitz's prior legal representation of Epstein, specifically in negotiating a controversial plea deal, which the plaintiff seeks to explore through discovery.

persons.name: Patrick Kessler
persons.context: Individual referenced in a New York Times article who allegedly brought forward a scheme similar to the one Dershowitz claims Giuffre's lawyers engaged in. There is a recording of a conversation between Kessler and Dershowitz.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Epstein's associate. Her deposition from a separate case (Giuffre v. Maxwell) is under a protective order but may be relevant to discovery in this case.

persons.name: Leslie Wexner
persons.context: Businessman mentioned in connection with an alleged scheme similar to the one Dershowitz claims was perpetrated against him.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: British royal mentioned in passing regarding the authenticity of a photograph, which is cited as a potential topic for expert analysis.

persons.name: C. Cooper
persons.context: Attorney for the plaintiff, discussing plans to amend the complaint to add new claims against Alan Dershowitz, including defamation, revived state tort claims, and a Wiretap Act claim.

persons.name: H. Cooper
persons.context: Attorney for the defendant (likely Alan Dershowitz), arguing against the proposed amendments to the complaint, discussing motions to dismiss on futility grounds, and outlining discovery plans including subpoenas.

persons.name: The Court
persons.context: Presiding judge (likely Judge Loretta A. Preska given 'LAP' in case number) managing the hearing, questioning both sides on their motions and urging them to discuss issues before filing motions.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Attorney referenced in relation to a tape recording that is the subject of a potential Wiretap Act claim. The defense also plans to subpoena him and his firm for materials, potentially invoking the crime-fraud exception.

persons.name: Michael Kirk
persons.context: Partner of plaintiff's attorney C. Cooper, introduced to the court at the end of the hearing.

persons.name: Nicole Moss
persons.context: Colleague of plaintiff's attorney C. Cooper, introduced to the court at the end of the hearing.

persons.name: Haley Proctor
persons.context: Colleague of plaintiff's attorney C. Cooper, introduced to the court at the end of the hearing.

persons.name: Mr. Aidala
persons.context: Attorney on the defense team who entered the courtroom, acknowledged by the judge.

persons.name: Ms. Giuffre
persons.context: Referenced indirectly as 'she' and 'plaintiff.' The core of the lawsuit involves her allegations. The defense argues she cannot avail herself of the Child Victims Act because she was not a child, citing potential employment records from Mar-a-Lago.

connections.description: Giuffre alleges Dershowitz sexually abused her; Dershowitz denies ever meeting her and is suing her for defamation.
Dershowitz had a 'decades-long friendship' with Epstein and was involved in defending him and negotiating a non-prosecution agreement.
Giuffre's allegations stem from her time with Epstein, whom she accuses of trafficking her.
Cooper is lead counsel representing plaintiff Virginia Giuffre in the defamation suit against Dershowitz.
Howard Cooper is lead counsel representing defendant Alan Dershowitz in the defamation suit.
There is a recorded conversation between Dershowitz and Kessler, mentioned in a New York Times article about an alleged scheme.
Giuffre has sued Maxwell separately; Maxwell's deposition from that case is relevant to discovery here.
Dershowitz represented Epstein legally, specifically in negotiating the controversial non-prosecution agreement in Florida. The plaintiff seeks discovery into this relationship.
C. Cooper is acting as legal counsel for the plaintiff, Ms. Giuffre, in her defamation lawsuit against Alan Dershowitz.
H. Cooper is acting as legal counsel for the defendant, Alan Dershowitz, in the defamation lawsuit brought by Ms. Giuffre.
Implied relationship. Boies was apparently taped, and the plaintiff is seeking a Wiretap Act claim related to that tape, suggesting he was involved in her legal matters.
Dershowitz is the defendant in a defamation lawsuit filed by Giuffre. She alleges he made defamatory statements about her.

Contextually implied. The case revolves around allegations related to Epstein. The defense seeks records about Giuffre's alleged employment at Mar-a-Lago to challenge her status under the Child Victims Act.

events.title: Discovery Conference in Giuffre v. Dershowitz
events.description: Court hearing before Judge Loretta Preska to discuss and limit the scope of discovery in the defamation lawsuit.

events.title: Negotiation of Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Reference to Dershowitz's involvement in defending Jeffrey Epstein and negotiating a non-prosecution agreement for him.

events.title: New York Times Article on Patrick Kessler
events.description: Article published the weekend before the hearing describing allegations by Patrick Kessler about a scheme involving lawyers, which Dershowitz's counsel claims is similar to the alleged extortion scheme against Dershowitz.

events.title: Publication of Dershowitz's Book
events.description: Alan Dershowitz published a book on the subject of the allegations, which the plaintiff claims contains fresh defamatory statements, prompting a planned amendment to the complaint.

events.title: Court Hearing on Case Management
events.description: A hearing before Judge Preska to discuss the plaintiff's intent to amend the complaint, the defense's opposition, and to schedule discovery, including issues around attorney-client privilege and the Child Victims Act.

events.title: Enactment of NY Child Victims Act
events.description: New York legislation that revived previously time-barred state tort claims for child sexual abuse victims. The plaintiff seeks to add claims under this act.

events.title: Negotiation of Epstein's Plea Deal
events.description: Referenced event where Alan Dershowitz represented Jeffrey Epstein in negotiating a controversial non-prosecution agreement in Florida. The plaintiff seeks discovery into this to understand motivations.

events.title: Recording of David Boies
events.description: A microcassette tape recording of attorney David Boies, which forms the basis for a potential Wiretap Act claim the plaintiff wishes to add to the complaint.

locations: Mar-a-Lago (referenced as a place of alleged employment for the plaintiff)
Florida (referenced in relation to Jeffrey Epstein's plea deal)
New York (jurisdiction for the Child Victims Act and the court hearing)
Washington (mentioned by the judge as being 'far' but accessible)
keyFacts: The core dispute is whether Alan Dershowitz and Virginia Giuffre had sexual relations, with Dershowitz denying ever meeting her and claiming he has only had sex with his wife for many years.
Dershowitz's defense includes an allegation that Giuffre, along with her lawyers, engaged in a conspiracy to fabricate claims against him for purposes of extortion or blackmail.
Another woman, besides Giuffre, has allegedly testified under oath that she had sex with Dershowitz in connection with Epstein's operation.
A recorded conversation exists between Dershowitz and Patrick Kessler, mentioned in a New York Times article, which Dershowitz's counsel believes supports their extortion conspiracy theory.
Judge Preska is attempting to narrowly focus discovery on travel documents, employment records, and core allegations to avoid a sprawling investigation into all aspects of the Epstein case.
The plaintiff plans to amend the defamation complaint to include new statements made by Alan Dershowitz in a recently published book.
The plaintiff intends to add state tort claims revived by the New York Child Victims Act, which the defense argues is futile because they claim to have proof she was not a child at the relevant time.
The defense plans to seek discovery, including subpoenas to David Boies and his firm, potentially invoking the crime-fraud exception to pierce attorney-client privilege.

The plaintiff seeks discovery into Alan Dershowitz's attorney-client relationship with Jeffrey Epstein, specifically regarding the negotiation of Epstein's controversial Florida plea deal, to explore Dershowitz's motivations.
The defense references seeking records related to the plaintiff's alleged employment at Mar-a-Lago to challenge her ability to claim status under the Child Victims Act.
